Reviews.Author: Robert K. Chin "fopclerk"
Reviews.Content: as was expected from Canon.great looking shots with point and shoot simplicity.Pro quality and fewer choices has made this a fun camera.will take the camera out more often as it is small and lighter than my other Canons

Reviews.Title: Canon wins again!
Reviews.Author: Susan Stretch "Susan"
Reviews.Content: Great purchase, clarity of picture fantastic, nothing beats my last Canon and this one is great as well.  I tried a Nikon in between Canons and will never buy another brand.  This is light weight, quick to focus and takes great pics.  Even our kids noticed the picture quality.  Also easy to use.

Reviews.Title: Lightweight, fast, defined images
Reviews.Author: stefano sanvito
Reviews.Content: The SL1 is the last of a long EOS history.After long years this new camera is lightweight and smaller dimensions but it keeps high definition and bright images in every light condition.Interesting feature is the night-shot system that take 4 images and realize one single final image with low noise.battery is smaller too but it's enough for a minimum of 400 / 450 shots.

Reviews.Title: Better than the 7D!
Reviews.Author: Wayne Wilson
Reviews.Content: This is currently the best crop sensor camera you can buy right now.It's odd, because it's also one of the cheapest DSLR's Canon sells, but the nature of the game, is that Canon introduces the best technology into their more expensive lines first, the 7D in 2009, for example. The same sensor technology and advances has then been put into each successive camera, the T3i, the T4i, the 60D, etc., and finally, it has trickled down into the Eos SL1.Having used the 7D, the 60D, and the SL1, I can say the SL1's user friendliness and ease of use is up with the 7D, and indeed better than the 60D or the T2i (haven't used T4 or the new T5). Another strange thing about Canon, is they'll sometimes put really neat features into their lower end cameras to kind of see how they work out, as a test of sorts.The reason I say the SL1 is better than the 7D is the 7D had the digic 4 processor while this has the digic 5 processor. sensors being even identical, the better processor will enhance noise reduction in low light shooting, and the speed of the processor being 6 times faster adds to snappyness all around.The SL1 does indeed have a touch screen, and actually, it's very useable, close to using an iphone in touch sensitivity, and the beauty of Canon's design is, you can turn it OFF, and you can navigate all the menus without using it at all either, which is something very important to me. I don't want my nose hitting the screen to suddenly change a setting while looking through the viewfinder, or maybe i want to save that extra bit of battery life, etc.it is indeed small, and my only real beef with the SL1 is that while the whole point of it is it being small and portable as all heck, my hand wants just a little bit more depth in the grip itself. otherwise, a perfect little camera. I'm sure some third party vendor is going to come out with an extension grip, or one of those hand strap accessories to remedy this.I wear glasses, and this viewfinder will be smaller than a 5DmkIII or 7D, and again don't like my nose smashing on the screen, so, I HIGHLY recommend the EP-EX15II extender for the viewfinder. Just look it up on amazon. it makes using the viewfinder infinitely more useable, and it's a very inexpensive accessory.That being said, I think Canon has a winner on their hands. I will take the SL1 + 40mm pancake combo over the FujiX100S or even Canon's G1X, or any other compact, 4/3's, or other 'lightweight' body camera. This is the one to beat!people complain about the 'only one cross-type' sensor, but I've found the autofocus points to be speedy and smart and accurate. The only time this should even be an issue is when holding the camera vertical/portrait mode, but what I tend to do is half-press to focus the center point where I want focus, and then compose the shot with button still pressed, then push all the way to take the shot. even with 20 cross-type focus sensors, you're better off just using the center to get focus anyways. At least, that's how I shoot.One other caveat is you should get at least one STM lens for this body. The kit lens is probably good, I didn't get it, the 40mm STM is a beautiful lens, perfect wide open, so at least get one STM lens, so you can appreciate the very fast focus speed and better autofocus during video shooting. An STM on this body makes autofocus during video actually possible and useable! a feat Canon had not accomplished until now.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: eleckh
Reviews.Content: I bought this as a less obvious body to use with my Canon lens.  My main Canon is a Eos 5 Mk III.  This is much much smaller and when used with my 40MM pancake lens is almost like a point and shoot in size.  It is a full quality SLR that takes all Canon lens.  I have no complaint about picture quality.  It does not have some of the features of the 5 Mk III, but at around 15% of the cost, you can't have everything.  It works very well for any type of pictures.

Reviews.Title: Great beginner camera with Auto features as well as features to grow into!
Reviews.Author: C. Pinchon
Reviews.Content: This is my first DSLR camera that my husband got our family last year. Like most people who enter the world of DSLR I was looking for better pictures of my kid and vacation pictures. Not trying to be a pro. Before this, I was using a Canon S95 point and shoot which is a decent point and shoot but I disliked the noise and general fuzziness I would get in the wrong light.SL1 pros: Small (ish) for a DSL, but with a good hand grip for me (husband says its too shallow for his hands). Lots of auto features ("scene" modes and creative auto) as well as features for more advance users (Aperture priority, full manual). With the kit lens (18-55) the pictures come out OK and sharp and the kit lens is good for video since the camera can record video and the kit lens has quiet autofocus that doesn't record in the video. But the zoom ring is a bit stiff and using it for the first time in a video it was a bit jerky. The aperture isn't that great on the kit lens, so I hardly use it anymore. (I like my nifty fifty most of the time).Image quality: very good. I've gotten a lot of compliments on my photos taken with this camera and with good light, I get very good photos. Images are sharp and although I edit them, for the most part, the colors are excellent. The kit lens has image stabilization (which I need!) but the body doesn't have any so when I combine my prime lenses (50mm 1.8 nifty fifty and 85mm 1.8 portrait lens) I can get slightly out of focus images because I think I have a slight wobble. Sucks. It's technique mostly.Noise above 6400 is a bit too much for my taste so I restricted it in the menu options. Wish it had built in lever guides (come on Canon!) and the more advance features coming to entry level mirror less cameras (Olympus, Panasonic).Overall design is nice and the touch screen can be used for touching the setting you want to change and then using the dial to alter it (such as aperture, or white balance). The touch screen doesn't swivel or tilt (it's fixed) but I like how you can touch to autofocus and take a picture right after (I used this to get kids interested in taking photos (since its easier than viewing in the viewfinder and pressing a shutter). Shooting in live mode with the LCD screen the autofocus is undoubtedly slower. But I fixed it onto a tripod and shot in live mode with a basic shutter cable and my images are tack sharp. I was taking pictures of kids posing for a new yearbook photo.No wi fi which is strange since it came out only last year.Can be used with most EF and EF-S lenses (I only own 4 including 2 kit lenses) and I've used it on a tripod with great success with a remote shutter (not super great) and the corded shutter with extension (much better!).I've taken this traveling to Europe and with the 4 lenses and hot shoe flash, I have to carry a large carry-on bag onto the airplane cabin since its just too much stuff and I would never pack a camera inside a suitcase. I suppose it would be a good addition for someone who has a larger Canon DSLR body and just wants a more portable version to go with their gear.I'd say this camera is great for beginners (like myself) to intermediate at the best. It does support high speed sync (which is a more advance feature I am trying out) but the built in flash cannot be used as a Master flash (you'd have to buy a hot shoe flash that supports being a master).

Reviews.Title: Amazing piece of art!
Reviews.Author: David Berrío "David Berrío"
Reviews.Content: If you're a beginner, this camera is one of the best (if not, the best) options to get into serious photography.If you're a pro, this is the camera to take everywhere without compromising portability or picture quality and without risking your other expensive pro-level cameras.I bought this as a backup camera for my 5D MIII. Also to use it as my personal cam. I was pleasantly surprised when I received it. It's small size is just amazing, specially when you put it side by side with the 5DMIII. Feels very comfortable, and the fact that I can use all of my canon lenses is the best thing.After using it for a few months, I have to say I take it always with me (which I couldn't do with the 5D).

Reviews.Title: No complaints about the SL1/100D
Reviews.Author: designerfin
Reviews.Content: I bought this as a second to my 7D and I really enjoy using it. The 7D is still better with RAW files at high ISO somehow (maybe due to having two processors), but I like having the better focusing for video, in-camera HDR and the brilliant implementation of the touch screen interface on the SL1/100D. However if small and light are your highest priority you might want a micro four thirds system due to smaller, lighter lenses. Too bad MFT is no less expensive. Reviewers seem to rate the comparable Nikon/Sony APS-C sensor a little higher, but overall I like the Canon camera better. Paired with the 40mm f2.8 you have a small, light rig that takes very sharp images. I'm not at all disappointed with my purchase.

Reviews.Title: Great DSLR for snapshooters who want to learn more advanced photography
Reviews.Author: Sarge
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for my wife, and she loves it.  She was ready to make the jump from her Canon Powershot to a DSLR but was put off by the size, weight, and apparent complexity (not so, but that's a conversation for a different time and place) of my 40D and 60D.I won't go into all the features and functions, or the benefits of a DSLR over a P&S.;  These are adequately covered in the product description and by other reviewers.  I'll just say this camera is of the same high quality design and build that experienced Canon shooters have come to expect.A few general observations:The 18-55mm STM kit lens is excellent (maybe the best in it's class), with a good zoom range for general scenics and casual portraits.  If the kit lens is the only one you have, it might be worth paying more for the 18-135mm for the extra reach.  It works fine with the lenses, including a couple of L models, I use on my XXDs.  But they're quite a bit larger and heavier than the kits and detract somewhat from size and weight benefit of this camera.Get a lens hood.I have my XXDs configured for back button focusing.  Can't do that with this one.  I'm left eye dominant and the back buttons are too close to my face.  It's awkward.The battery is probably the weakest aspect of this camera.  In order to keep the weight low, Cannon uses a smaller lower capacity battery.  Because of the way we shoot we can easily get though several days of casual shooting on a single charge.  But if you're always checking your shots, shoot in bursts, often use the built in flash, or use live view, you'll want a backup battery.  Maybe two if you shoot much video.  We bought a low cost third party battery that seems to work just fine.The video function seems to work OK.  I'm not a videographer and have no interest in becoming one.  I doubt that I'll use this function much, if at all.  I had a colleague, who is an accomplished videographer, look at this feature.  His assessment is that it works well, but one who shoots a lot of video should buy a dedicated video camera.  Says he wouldn't recommend it to record the only video of an important event like a graduation or wedding.This is an excellent choice for someone who's just getting into DSLR photography, or an experienced photographer who wants a second high quality body without breaking the bank.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: sdrizzle
Reviews.Content: Light, compact and very easy to use . Would highly recommend and takes amazing photos. Great for the novice photographer.

Reviews.Title: Great great product
Reviews.Author: Lokesh
Reviews.Content: I love my camera. Just got back from a Machu picchu trip and thats why I bought the camera - this totally served the purpose and took great photographs. The box standard lens is good but if you feel you want to take pictures of far away objects then get a 18 to 135 mm lens (I would've bought it that way but no one offers it as a kit and the lens alone with the camera body didnt work out economical).Anyway, its very light and easy to hold - contrary to other comments, I did not find it hard to hold and my hands are not small. I plan to take this every time I go on holiday.. its very light on the shoulder and neck which is very important for day trips.

Reviews.Title: Lighteight to carry; not lightweigh in performance
Reviews.Author: Jennifer Hicks
Reviews.Content: I began photography with a Brownie camera bout 40 years ago. Clearly, times have changed.  I've used several high-end DSLRs, and more recently a point-and-shoot that has way more things than I know how to control -- but I could carry it, even though I didn't particularly like it.  Meant I could still take "pics" if not photos.  Perhaps I am odd, going from a recent Canon DSLR to its newest Rebel. But, it had become so that I couldn't use the massive camera and keep it steady -- and I had the choice to carry it or the tripod -- not a good photo mix having to choose between the two.  So, first... No, the Rebel SL1 doesn't take the same kind of pics as the bigger DSLR-- but it **does** take photos as opposed to pics, and I can carry it -- and the tripod.  And for me, that matters.  The photos are good, (not award winning -- yet).  Their resolution is fine; little tweaks in Photoshop can make them better.  But the best?  I can carry the bloody thing (and the tripod); interchange lightweight lenses; and feel happy at the end of the day. If you're a photo-pro, this might be an OK walk-around-with camera that does more than point-and-shoot.  If you want more than that, it likely won't satisfy you. However, if you are a photo hobbyist that likes being able to take really good photos easily, and can't carry the weight of a full-size DSLR (crap... getting older and less-abled is really unpleasant), you might just find this is the camera you're looking for.(Edit:)  Changed to 5 stars when not using kit lens. See comments.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: JanisJ
Reviews.Content: I chose this camera primarily for its size and weight, and am delighted with its performance.  Excellent photos.  Instructions are comprehensive and easy to follow.  Rapid focus.  No time lag. Love the macro lens.

Reviews.Title: Amazing value/ Great camera
Reviews.Author: Eric m
Reviews.Content: I am very impressed with the value this camera brings to the table. I am a novice photographer with a baby on the way. This camera is everything we could have asked for. It's small and lightweight. I am an average sized guy and I don't mind the size.  The photo quality is amazing and I can't wait to use it more. I will come back here after a few months to review it after I have used it for awhile.

Reviews.Title: Great starter SLR camera
Reviews.Author: Ashlee
Reviews.Content: I was eager to see if this new smaller version of the SLR camera made by Canon would be up to par of Canon's other SLR cameras despite its supposedly small size. In testing it out I figured It would be a great start camera for those who have never used a SLR camera and those who are used to point and shoot cameras would definitely see a difference in picture quality. It's small size and lightweight body makes it easier to grip especially for those who have smaller hands. I tote this camera around because it's light weight and it still brings a excellent quality photo. It's one of my favorite Canon cameras to use, mainly because of the smaller size of the body of the camera. However the lens is a standard size, but it's nothing to worry about as the lens that comes with the kit isn't too heavy anyways. Compared to Canon's other cameras I did noticed the difference in resolution of the picture between the larger cameras than the SL1's but this is nothing to send you away from this camera but this comes with the size of the camera and lens. It definitely still has a great resolution(for large prints)and excellent picture quality. I would definitely recommend the Canon EOS Rebel SL1 camera for someone who is looking for an entry-level SLR camera.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: D. Leeds
Reviews.Content: As the other posts claim, this thing is small.  It is very small in your hands.  I can't quite get my hand positioned comfortably, but it is a great device and I would recommend it to women or men with hands on the small side.

Reviews.Title: Smallest current DSLR!
Reviews.Author: Cobra
Reviews.Content: A great little DSLR.  While we opted to return it for a Fuji X100S, we were remarkably pleased with this SL1 Rebel in general.  If you truly want a small quality DSLR . . . this is the one!

Reviews.Title: Canon EOS Rebel SL1
Reviews.Author: Maury Swoveland
Reviews.Content: I have been using this camera for about 4 months now. Purchased with an Amazon vendor with a complete kit for a great price. I used SLR back in the 70's with film, so the features of this camera are quite different for me. The feature set of the camera, for something this small and inexpensive is amazing. The size is small but the camera fits in the had very well. Buttons for quick functions are well placed and easy to use. I absolutely love the touch screen display. But in truth, I rarely use "live view" for taking pictures. The viewfinder is not 100% of what the lens sees, but it is so easy to use, and easy to find your subject, unlike the point and shoot I used before. What is really amazing about this camera is the auto focus (AF). It is 9 point, but I find mostly I use the "spot" focus. The pictures that I am able to get amaze me. How the camera can focus as quickly as it does is something. I find myself now using "M" more and more to adjust the shutter speed and aperture for detailed and fast moving subjects. I have been able to take pictures of birds in flight, near and far that are in focus and with great detail. Although I may someday upgrade to a midrange DSLR, this camera will have given me all the "lessons" I need to be able to handle the additional features that midrange DSLR's have. If you have a point and shoot (I had every HS xx IS now HS model made) than you will love this camera. Get yourself at least a 300mm lens (I have a 70 300mm from ebay) and take some pretty amazing wildlife photo's. This camera will fit any EF lens Canon or others (like the Tamron 150 600mm) make. Great camera body!

Reviews.Title: Excellent Camera
Reviews.Author: Icomowner
Reviews.Content: This is my 4th Canon digital SLR. I am very happy with it and especially with its small size and weight! It will accept the Canon family of lenses and accessories. Excellent photos, especially when shooting in RAW.

Reviews.Title: In love with this Camara
Reviews.Author: Erika
Reviews.Content: Overall I think this is an amazing camera. The pictures are amazing in quality and the Sl1 can do so much for such a small size. I think this is perfect DSLR for a beginner or someone who just doesn't like to carry the other DSLR's.

Reviews.Title: Love this thing
Reviews.Author: Michael Goodman
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera with a great default lens. I bought a mini fold-out trippod which is really easy to carry around as well (it's basically camping tent poles and fold really easily). This thing made my recent trip to Iceland SO much better. 30 second exposures of the northern lights...beautiful pictures.The body is smaller than most DSLR cameras, making it more travel friendly as well. But it still has all the features of the full-sized ones, apparently. The lens is really nice too. Solid construction. I actually dropped the thing (rather, wind knocked it down from a tripod) and fell at the corner of the lens and on the body...not a single hiccup. Solid.Also, surprisingly, there is a food setting which the manual comically said it will make food appear more tasty...totally written by some Japanese guy who doesn't know English very well. But then again, that setting rocks for food...the food does look more tasty! Yay Japan ^_^

Reviews.Title: AWESOME CAMERA
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Proud American"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera to upgrade from my 35mm Elan 7 film camera. Each year I would scrutinize the new Rebel cameras being released to the same result, I wasn't happy with what was available so I waited. Well, I couldn't be happier that I waited as long as I did because the features on this camera are outstanding, I believe anyone that purchases this camera will be very happy.

Reviews.Title: This is an Awesome Powerful DSLR.
Reviews.Author: Quentin J Buffington
Reviews.Content: I purchased this so I would not have to haul out my big 5D MK II. I could use almost all of my current equipment and have a much smaller camera body that was family event friendly and still give me excellent image quality. So far I have not been disappointed. The interface is very intuitive, the camera feels solid and your hands and fingers seem to just fit right where they need to go. I love the image quality and enjoy this camera more and more as I use it.

Reviews.Title: Just got it...
Reviews.Author: Elizabeth
Reviews.Content: And am only shooting in the preset modes right now. Still, this is an absolutely fabulous camera to me, coming from a point and shoot.I have small hands, and find this a wonderful size. It's so light, as well.I have a lot to learn about shooting with this, but I can tell it is going to be a lot of fun learning as I go along.The image quality is terrific. I posted a few shots of my dog going after snow-balls in the image gallery. I caught the snow flying! I am so thrilled!

Reviews.Title: Very good camera for those with hands small enough to hold it comfortably
Reviews.Author: D. Johnson
Reviews.Content: The Canon Rebel SL1 is a great camera.  It pretty much takes the majority of features of a T5i and crams them into a smaller body.  Image quality is very good (though possibly not as good as what Nikon offers at this price point), and the camera is very responsive.Its biggest asset, though, is its size.  It really is tiny.  And light.  It's hard to imagine how the workings of an SLR camera can be fit into something so small and lightweight.Its biggest liability, though, is its size.  It really is tiny.  If you've got larger than average-size hands (or maybe even average size hands), it may be a little uncomfortable to hold it.  The hand grip doesn't go very deep, so larger fingers have no comfortable place to go.  My hands are pretty normally sized, if not slightly smaller than normal, and I found the camera to be just a bit uncomfortable to hold for long periods of time.  Certainly not because of the weight.  But because I never could get my hands into a position that really fit properly.  The grip just isn't quite big enough to be the right fit.  I may be spoiled because normally I shoot with a Canon 6D or 70D, which fit my hands very well, but the SL1 never feels quite right.But for someone with small hands, or someone who is looking for a tiny SLR, the SL1 is great.  Just make sure to try one on for size before purchasing to make sure it is something you can work with comfortably.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for the "family" photographer
Reviews.Author: D. Sapp
Reviews.Content: this is the 4th Canon EOS camera I have had.  Each has been an incremental upgrade. I though this would be the same, however, this camera represents a significant step up from the T series cameras.  It's compact size is a little interesting to get used to when it is paired with a larger lens - the lens weighs more than the camera. Photo quality and its ability to handle a variety of light conditions with few changes make it the ideal for taking sharp photos of the grand kids on the move. Love this camera.

Reviews.Title: New to SLR but love it
Reviews.Author: H. Turner
Reviews.Content: This is my 1st and only experience with a SLR but it takes great pics, is easy to use, and the battery lasts a long time.  I also like that it is small but adding lenses makes it bigger anyways.  I wish it had a string from the lens caps.

Reviews.Title: Love this camera
Reviews.Author: Sarah Pond Maloney
Reviews.Content: I just got this new Canon over the weekend, and I love it. First of all, it's size. It's very light! The grip was a little hard to get used to; I felt at first that it was too small but in no time I got used to it and don't even notice it. I have fairly small hands. For really big hands, I think it might be awkward. As a novice photographer, I am guilty of overuse on the auto setting, but I was determined to explore this camera, and glad I did! The grainy black and white setting is really fun to use, as are the other scene settings, such as food (yes, food does look better for all the instagram-ers out there), kids, etc..and I found that the M setting along with forced flash produced a much cleaner, less orange glow to the image than using Auto some of the time, especially in a room with adequate lighting but the subject might be in the shadows. I also got the 40mm pancake lens that I had some trouble with, and not sure why...I think I was asking too much of it in low-light settings, perhaps? The lens that accompanied the camera is wonderful. Light weight, easy to use, great images. This is a great alternative to the big, heavy DSLR's, but with the high MP (18) I think it will produce higher quality photos than the affordable mirror-less cameras.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic camera
Reviews.Author: Betty Ganung
Reviews.Content: Just received this camera last week. Have taken 200 photos already and am very impressed. The autofocus is quick and very accurate. Love the touch screen. Haven't learned all the settings yet but what a improvement over the last of the Rebel line. Love the size and weight. Controls are easy to access. Would definitely recommend this to anyone who loves photography without all thecomplicated settings.

Reviews.Title: Filmmakers Looking for a Good Camera, Look No Further!
Reviews.Author: Curtis Everitt
Reviews.Content: If you want a camera that shoots extremely vibrant video while eliminating some of the older camera problems experienced by past DSLR's, the Canon SL1 is fantastic.  It's lightweight, which means that it won't be a brick on top of any of your tripods, and going handheld with it is much more comfortable.  Paired with a fixed 50mm Canon lens, this camera produces extremely high quality video.  Not to mention it's extremely affordable, going for way less than other cameras.  If you're a beginner filmmaker looking to put your money into a camera that won't let you down, make sure to get one of these cameras.  Also, purchase a 50mm lens, one 16gb memory card, an external hard drive, and a decent pistol grip tripod, and you'll be good to go!

Reviews.Title: Wonderful Camera, poor Quality Control.
Reviews.Author: S. Flaherty
Reviews.Content: I had a Nikon D600, which I loved.  I like to take pictures of birds every day at a nearby lake, though, and the Nikon with the 70-300 lens was very heavy and hurting my shoulder.  I saw the SL1,w as impressed by its size and decided to try it.  I love the camera, but Canon needs to step up their quality control.  The first unit I had stopped auto focusing after a week and had to be returned.  I am not at all rough on equipment.  The second unit had two large specks on the sensor that showed as big globs in my pictures.  Once I got a decent (fingers crossed) unit, I took raw and jpeg fine pictures and compared it with my Nikon D600, and for what I do, there is no obvious difference in the units.  I ended up selling my D600 and my shoulder thanks me for it.  I can carry it easily and feel hardly any weight, since the camera and 55-250 lens is 2 pounds, much less than my heavier Nikon.  I do not shoot at high iso speeds, but at 200 or 400 there is no noticeable noise.  I really like the fact that you can see your settings, and change them as well, on the LCD screen.  I'm very happy with this purchase.  I would give it 5 stars if I hadn't received two defective units.

Reviews.Title: A great second body, but the stock lens is limiting
Reviews.Author: Bill M
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for those occasions when lugging around my EOS 7D was not an option. The sensor and image processor are the same as those in the 7D, but the autofocus is much less sophisticated and the camera has fewer bells and whistles. So far neither of these has been an issue.  The limiting factor has been the short zoom range of the stock 18-55 mm zoom lens.  I think Canon went overboard here in an effort to keep weight and cost down. If this were my only lens, I'd be very unhappy. However, the SL-1 body paired with the stock 18-135 mm IS zoom from the 7D makes an excellent camera that's still quite small and light. I don't use 90% of the features on the 7D, so I don't miss them on the SL-1, and I'm old-school enough that I don't mind putting the lens into manual focus when I need to. My only issue is finding a case that works with the longer lens.

Reviews.Title: You’ll want to take pictures every day!
Reviews.Author: N. SMITH
Reviews.Content: For 6 months now, I can still say I love this camera.  It is my first digital single lens reflex camera that I’ve ever owned, and it is perfect.I like that it is small, lightweight, and takes beautiful high quality images.If you want to see the high quality of images it can take, you can view the 7,000+ photos on the Canon EOS 100D/EOS Rebel SL1 - Official Group right here on Flickr [...]Lots of other Amazon reviewers have listed the differences between this camera and the T5i or more high end cameras.  Let’s face it.  You are looking at this camera because you don’t want to haul around a big, heavy, clunky camera just to take nice photos.  Your ego does not need to be defined by the size of your lens.In fact, I suggest that you just purchase the camera body alone, and buy smaller lenses as you can afford them.  Using a Canon EF 40mm f/2.8 STM Lens keeps your SL1 lightweight and modest.I tend to take pictures of my kids, vacation trips, and family events such as birthdays.  My goal is not to look like the paparazzi when photographing. This camera is as simple as taking pictures with your phone, but provides the professional look that no camera phone can accomplish.The helpful menu features on the camera explain what each mode does which is perfect for the novice.  It is easy to make quick adjustments and the creative modes are fun.  I particularly enjoy the touch screen display for more intuitive selections.Remember, you want a high quality camera, that’s compact so you can take it everywhere.  If you have hands the size of Shaquille O'Neal than perhaps you might want something bigger.  Nearly everyone should be able to take beautiful pictures with this camera comfortably though.Try it! Buy it!  You'll love it!Other suggested purchases:Canon EF 40mm f/2.8 STM Lens - Awesomely small compact lens great for low lighting, blurred backgrounds, and landscapes.Canon EF 70-300mm f/4.5-5.6 DO IS USM Lens - Great for a zoom lens that's compactCanon EF-S 18-135mm f/3.5-5.6 IS STM  - 18mm is good for wide angles and the 135mm is a nicer zoom than the kit lens.Canon LP-E12 Battery Pack - Always good to have a 2nd batteryLightscoop Deluxe - Great when using the on camera flash.  Allows you to bounce flash off the ceiling, wall or other directions to create softer lighting.Now go take some pictures!

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Ryan
Reviews.Content: This was a refurbished camera, but still looks and performs like a brand new one. Great quality and photos. Perfect for a beginner and intermediate photographer.

Reviews.Title: Great little Camera, UNBELIEVABLE video capabilities.
Reviews.Author: Daniel Mckinnon "danielmckinnon"
Reviews.Content: I mostly bought this camera for its video abilities, as I love the look of DSLR video, and the quality is unmatched by other video cameras in the same price range.  I didn't see a lot of reviews mentioning this specifically, so I thought i'd contribute. I chose this one specifically because of its STM lens which features silent, continuous auto-focus during video recording. Needless to say, I am very impressed. I tried the video capabilities out by shooting a friend's wedding proposal, and some little congratulatory interviews with friends and family. After some post-production work in Final Cut, the video that came out of this camera was unmatched. After posting the video online, I got several responses from others looking to employ me as videographer for their own events. It is truly professional quality in video, and I would venture to say that you couldn't find video quality like this without paying at least double what this costs.The manual video setting on this are fantastic; being able to manually adjust exposure, aperture, framerate, shutter speed, etc.. really lets you get just the right look for what you are shooting. and the tap-to-focus abilities really give you the control to get professional looking focus sweeps and adjustments during video, without the noisy refocusing that previous ten DSLRs were plagued by.The photos are also very good, but I haven't done much photo shooting with it yet.It should be noted however, that the audio captured by DSLRs during video recording is abysmal. I equipped this with the Azden shotgun mic, and it works great and is a proper video machine.

Reviews.Title: Cool little camera
Reviews.Author: Jacko
Reviews.Content: Love it especially if I use one of my large Canon lenses on it.I have the bigger cameras as well but this if fun to carry every where.

Reviews.Title: Nice Fit
Reviews.Author: Michael
Reviews.Content: I wanted a reasonably priced DSLR that is capable of taking nice photos but I also wanted something that wasn't too bulky and didn't feel like a toy. This SL1 fits my requirements nicely. It is a little bulkier than a GT6 it replaces but not by much. The SL1 fits nicely in my hand and the primary buttons and dials are easy to reach. The only two faults I have with it is that the screen doesn't articulate and the Fstop and shutter are set using the same dial meaning that you can't really control both while looking through the viewfinder. Overall, I'm pleased with this camera and would purchase it again.

Reviews.Title: great little camera
Reviews.Author: RudiHolt
Reviews.Content: I normally shoot with a 5Dmkiii but I needed something to walk around with and not worry about. This camera fits the bill. It is very small and light weight. Image quality is good. All the features you need. For the price it was a really good deal.

Reviews.Title: Looooooove this camera!
Reviews.Author: Erika Fradella "lucy lover"
Reviews.Content: I researched SLR cameras for over month and finally decided on this one and I'm so happy with my decision. This camera rocks my world! It's so easy to use and takes awesome pictures. I've never had an SLR camera before so I don't really have much to compare it too, but this camera is perfect for a newbie like myself. Plus it's much smaller than other cameras of its kind, which is great since I have small hands. I highly recommend this camera!

Reviews.Title: Love this camera
Reviews.Author: Sandesh Sreenivas
Reviews.Content: Got this on some flash sale for $460...great buy.  Almost settled for the T3i, but I'm glad I waited.  No complaints whatsoever.

Reviews.Title: super fast service
Reviews.Author: Harm R.
Reviews.Content: Camera was as as described like brand new. I do have several EOS cameras so this body helps to use my lenses.

Reviews.Title: Canon
Reviews.Author: roho
Reviews.Content: My wife loves it, and it seem to take great pictures. The biggest advantage is the smaller size most of the other DSLR I looked at had much bigger bodies and my wife has small hands.

Reviews.Title: Great
Reviews.Author: Biobench
Reviews.Content: Great product, functions very well, and am loving it.  We used our old lens that we bought over 8 years ago, but the images were amazing with this camera.

Reviews.Title: loved this camera
Reviews.Author: Mc1952
Reviews.Content: Takes great pictures, easy to use. Have had others similar but this is the best one I've had and highly recommend

Reviews.Title: Perfect
Reviews.Author: Pam M.
Reviews.Content: It's the perfect camera for me. It's much lighter and easier to hold than other models. I am not a expert by any means, but I have found the set up to be easy and taking pictures is a breeze. The quality of the images is also excellent. Great camera for the incidental photographer.

Reviews.Title: Great SL1 camera
Reviews.Author: Amdz13
Reviews.Content: Love this camera, super light weight , small size , very portable compare to others slr cameras. Good features, top of the line processor C5, excellent for beginners photographers or just hobby.

Reviews.Title: Good and Reliable
Reviews.Author: Brice
Reviews.Content: Nice for the money. We are not professionals but this is as close as we have come. This is an easy camera to use and the photo quality is very good.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic, Tiny Camera!
Reviews.Author: Robert Ray
Reviews.Content: Incredible amount of camera tucked into a tiny package. The low price point makes it even better... Highly recommended for a backup or even primary camera.

Reviews.Title: Absolutely Love it..!!
Reviews.Author: Gopal Ramasamy
Reviews.Content: This is an upgrade to my decade old EOS Digital Rebel (the first dslr camera from Canon). Awesome look and feel, very compact compared to their other models and is full featured. I bought only the body and paired it with the Tamron 18-270mm zoom lens - seems to be a perfect combination.Love the features, except that fact that it doest have the feature where the touch screen can be popped out, rotated and closed like the T5i. Other than that, all the features are almost similar in a smaller frame. @ 350$, this is a steal..!! (the price has been fluctuating between 360 and 450 for some reason..)Love it!! Love it!!  Love it!!  Will recommend it highly if you are upgrading from an older dslr. Otherwise too, if you are looking to get a good dslr, give this a fair chance..!! The small form factor is the best feature of this camera.

Reviews.Title: Great Value!
Reviews.Author: Randy
Reviews.Content: I spent a lot of time researching cameras for great family shots.  it came down to portability, brand reputation and past experiences.  I have owned a Canon G9 for several years and it has been extremely durable but I wanted more flexibility as I learned to take better photos.  I used the SL1 at Christmas (2013) and I love it the photos using only the built in flash and auto setting were excellent.  I saw a demo on line that recommended the 18-55mm lens to start as you learn the camera and I would agree.I would not hesitate to recommend it to friends.

Reviews.Title: The new offering from canon - SL1
Reviews.Author: K. Streber "Gadget Hound"
Reviews.Content: What a great little camera. Easy to use features. Love the description that comes up on the display when you select a feature. Display is great with some touch and swipe type features. 18 mega pixels provides an awesome image, you can shoot in both JPEG and raw. To many things to say about it. Love the size, not to small, just right!

Reviews.Title: new Canon SL 1
Reviews.Author: Mit "ten"
Reviews.Content: Just started using this camera, so far loving it! Takes raw in auto. takes low light well, movies I need to study more.

Reviews.Title: This camera is everything that it promises.
Reviews.Author: Alicia Johnson
Reviews.Content: The touch screen is super responsive and helpful. The setting are straight forward and easy to understand. All my other cannon EF lenses from the 90s fit on this body, which is fantastic. The user guide is helpful and the clarity of the pictures is fantastic. It was snowing dramatically on my last xc ski trip and the pictures still turned out wonderfully clear. Oh, and the size and weight are freaking great. I am a small woman with small hands, I have helped friends carry around their T3i and T5i and it was like carrying around a child! Not the SLR, besides not being able to get around the size of the lens, the body is practically the size of medium point and shoot models.

Reviews.Title: great camera
Reviews.Author: Fred Morse
Reviews.Content: I don't have sufficient experience with this yet to be certain, but so far this camera is superb. I am not a PRO so my demands may not equal the readers, but I am very fussy. I like it's light weight and smaller size. It is very straight forward to use in both manual and auto modes.  So far, the auto settings are similar to ones I set, when different, the camera was better.  I like the fact that it uses the lenses I bought over the years for my old 6 MP Rebel. I loved that camera and this one is better in so many ways.

Reviews.Title: Excellent size and price, with advantages of higher priced DSLRs
Reviews.Author: aatir
Reviews.Content: The SL1 performance is a wonderful experience which i was not expecting from such a compact DSLR. Thumbs up to Canon for this ( I am a novice photographer). Movie mode, quite lens (18-55 IS STM), quick AF, touch screen along with simple menu, compact size of SL1 (benefits of APSC DSLR), and image quality are some outstanding features. It would have been simply outstanding if articulating screen and WiFi feature were also present (no regrets on the good quality of touch screen tough IMO). Recommend for those looking for consistently good images, live view shooting, AF in movie mode and benefits of APSC DSLR in a roughly mirror-less camera compact size.

Reviews.Title: BECOME MORE CREATIVE!
Reviews.Author: mdgiv
Reviews.Content: To have something you can bring around without making everyone you want to take a picture of nervous is so awesome. This camera is so handy your photographic creativity will just flow in and fill your head up with what you can do with it.Great back up cam to have. You can dedicate your prime lens to it and keep the zoom in your primary cam. Also good for close up/ revolving second camera while taking videos and not distract the subject while you lock your primary cam on a tripod. I got spoiled with the quick setting changes because of the touchscreen and now I find myself touching the screen of my older camera.When i got it, I played around with it for 2 days will all my lenses. When I went back to my 60D for work related use, it felt so huge like a tank!Great product!

Reviews.Title: If You Want To Advance From Smartphone Pics This Is A Great Choice
Reviews.Author: L. Schuyler
Reviews.Content: The Sl1 is light, easy to operate, and allows creativity. I have had mine for a short while and am still experimenting, but so far I found I am more confident with the operations. Looking forward to taking holiday pictures.

Reviews.Title: Amazing SLR for beginners!
Reviews.Author: Hannah
Reviews.Content: Complete and utter novice here.  I'm just a regular person who wants to take higher quality photos.  I've gone through regular point and shoots in the past, and nowadays, my iphone is good enough for a daily picture taker.  I was looking for a starter DSLR camera that wouldn't be too complicated but also didn't want to go too remedial or cheap and sacrifice quality.  I also am not too keen on carrying around a huge and heavy camera all day.I was originally set on buying a Nikon but after doing my research I decided on the Canon based on quality, weight, and reviews and couldn't be happier with my purchase.  This camera fits perfectly in my hands, light and easy to tote around and the lens and quality of photos are great.  It's basic enough for beginners but you can also see just by playing around with the settings that it has the advances capabilities for you as you grow as a photographer.

Reviews.Title: As good as 7D or 60D at a fraction of price.
Reviews.Author: Mike90125
Reviews.Content: That's it. Instead of scrutinizing utterly worthless things like megapixels, it's simple: it delivers picture quality and noise performance on par with any Canon camera with this sensor, like the 60D and 7D, at a fraction of price. Tried everything from the Canon fisheye to the 800mm, and compared images from my 60D and 7D bodies, and it's just as good. With noise, often better at high ISOs, which should never be used anyway, but...Do not hesitate to buy the body for your prime, or a backup, for under $400 you have a fully capable DSLR body.

Reviews.Title: Very good starter
Reviews.Author: Ray "Ray"
Reviews.Content: This is my very first DSLR. Purchased about 5-6 months ago. I have been using it frequently ever since, and it's been a very awesome companion :) I think it's a good camera to start with, and it's super small for a DSLR. Not waterproof though!

Reviews.Title: Quality + approachable DSLR camera
Reviews.Author: New England Gal "M"
Reviews.Content: I've been using this camera a few months now and although I have much more "playing" to do with it to feel comfortable with all it's settings, so far I love it.  It is the perfect camera to transition into the world of DSLR.  I had many models of Canon powershot elph's before this...all fun to use, compact and good quality...but the Canon EOS Rebel was exactly what I needed to be able to take more professional looking photos and with greater speed.  I can even see improved photo quality (from my canon elph) when I put the Rebel on the "automatic" setting.  I checked out a few of the DSLR's in the store before buying this and the Canon EOS Rebel was better than the others because of the lighter weight and a more comfortable feeling in your hands.  Remember to get a comfortable neck strap to go with it though.

Reviews.Title: Sweet Camera
Reviews.Author: Talyra
Reviews.Content: This is a wonderful camera.  I love the touch screen and I am learning about all it has to offer.

Reviews.Title: Amazing Entry-Level DSLR for Professional/Hobbyist Photography!
Reviews.Author: Sean
Reviews.Content: This is the first DSLR camera I have ever owned, and I'm incredibly happy with the quality of the images.I have it with the standard 18/35mm lens and it has greatly increased my interest in doing professional photography.I've found that it's helped me with understanding the more technical features of cameras, and through experimentation I have taken some rather stunning photographs. People are paying attention, and it sounds like soon they will be paying me.

Reviews.Title: Huge step up
Reviews.Author: Charlie B
Reviews.Content: I hadn't updated my dslr for 4 years or so.  This one is better in almost every way.  I like the high iso settings, the movie mode (although with the internal microphone you hear the motor if you use autofocus), the ability to use the lcd to view a picture when I am shooting macro, and the when using the lcd that I can zoom in 10X so I can fine focus.

Reviews.Title: Great product
Reviews.Author: Jessica Owens
Reviews.Content: I love this camera. Great starter SLR to learn with. I would recommend to any one wanting to learn and use for good photography.

Reviews.Title: One of the best cameras out there
Reviews.Author: ROBERT M.
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my wife and she says its the best camera she's ever had. I've seen some of the pictures she's taken and they are astonishing. Amazon has a great price on this. Highly recommend.

Reviews.Title: Great entry level DSLR
Reviews.Author: James Hendrix Jr.
Reviews.Content: I have no need for a better camera.  This one has all the features I need for HDR work (oxphoto.org) and the compact size is great for long walks with a wrist strap.

Reviews.Title: I like it, but not in love
Reviews.Author: The Zedman
Reviews.Content: I had the old Canon Rebel, and that was a good camera. Really good. So good that I kept using the camera for years. But although the new Rebel (EOS 100D) is good and the image quality is brilliant, i'm not sold on the auto-focus, and by extension the auto-exposure. Maybe it's me and maybe i have a setting wrong, but the focus is a bit random and seems to shift ever so slightly when you're supposedly locked onto an image - and then the auto-exposure mucks up because the focus is out. Like I say, maybe it's me, but i never had this issue with the original Rebel. The old Rebel i took all around the world and took tens of thousands of photos and i never had this issue. But let's put this issue aside. The camera is light. I mean really light. This is good and bad. Good that it doesn't put a strain on your hand, but bad in that i like a bit of weight to the body to get crisp shots - and maybe this is the nub of earlier issue. I like all the features the camera comes with, although the in-camera filters are a bit of a waste, and i don't really use them. I'd rather have a solid perfect original that i can manipulate later in post, rather than having the original modified in-camera - leaving no opportunity for later tuning. Do watch the battery, as it will drain pretty quickly if you take a lot of photos, but if you're like me you'll always carry spare batteries (i always carry 3 spares). And to that point, the battery charger is damn quick. So if you do run out of power, it's not a long wait - a couple of hours. But you should always carry spares anyway, so the point is moot. I've also taken to using an Eye-Fi SD card. This is a little SD card that has built in wifi, and is compatible with this camera. So when my camera comes in range of my wifi (either at home, my iPad, or phone) the Eye-Fi card starts to upload the images. A real saver in time and I now wonder how I ever survived before by manually transferring images. I would have given this camera a 5-star rating but the focus issue is a real bug for me.

Reviews.Title: Real good stuff.
Reviews.Author: madpo
Reviews.Content: Real good stuff. Works. Thanks much! The only question I have is whether the super light weight makes a substantial difference in the steadiness of videos. I'm sure at least a little, but I've never really directly compared heavier vs. lighter. Just a thought.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera.
Reviews.Author: Kathleen Warren "picky broad"
Reviews.Content: I love the size, the weight and the picture quality.  Well worth the price.  The features also rock.  All in all, a great purchase.

Reviews.Title: I love this camera
Reviews.Author: MooVit11
Reviews.Content: Going from a 60D to save space, initially it feels a little small and strange with the smaller handle, but it takes great pictures.I plan to do a side by side comparison with my 60D.  If the picture quality is truly the same, I will be selling the 60D.The only thing I wish Canon would change is the LCD is basically useless unless you use a tripod  This is true on all Canon SLR I have used.The video is clear, but the constant focusing is a challenge for these SLR cameras.  I wouldn't buy it with the intent of using it for video often.

Reviews.Title: Great Small SLR
Reviews.Author: Benjamin D. Mcgill "musicman"
Reviews.Content: We love this camera; we find the smaller size makes the camera easy to carry and hold. It takes very nice pictures and has a good menu system.  You can set to automatic and get great pictures, or if you want to be creative the manual modes make it easy to play with aperture, shutter speed, iso, and of course you can immediately see the results on the large LCD and adjust accordingly. I also bought the EF 50MM lens for taking portraits , which is a great addition to the kit lens.This camera also has good consumer reports review; while I am sure that you can spend more money and better a better camera with more features, you definitely get a lot for your money with this model.

Reviews.Title: love this camera
Reviews.Author: Michelle L Jensen
Reviews.Content: I am really enjoying my new camera. It has lots of great features and take great pictures! Can't wait to keep shooting.

Reviews.Title: Light, small and gorgeous!
Reviews.Author: grace
Reviews.Content: It is indeed the smallest and lightest camera in Canon EOS series. I like it so much!! Highly recommended! Good quality and appearance.

Reviews.Title: good stuff
Reviews.Author: Marika E.
Reviews.Content: Perfect camera.  Great size. Great features.  Good value.  .  Gave a gift.  She loves it.  What more can I say?

Reviews.Title: Great Product! And Great Service
Reviews.Author: Gina
Reviews.Content: Product arrived on time, and was packaged very well! It was packed very securely to ensure it's safe arrival. We are very pleased with the product (so far no complaints). Takes sharp pictures, and was a great step up from our previous camera, which was an older point and shoot. Easy to use, but there is a lot more for us to learn. Thank-You for great service!!! Highly recommend!

Reviews.Title: Amazing camera
Reviews.Author: Diana
Reviews.Content: I love this camera! and the sixe is so handy.Just don't forget to get a memory card, like I did :)

Reviews.Title: Great size and features
Reviews.Author: chungwo
Reviews.Content: Support eye fi sd card compact dslr for a good price. Would have been better if the lens that came with it is a wider range lens

Reviews.Title: I love this camera
Reviews.Author: eh alden
Reviews.Content: Bought this for my wife who had been looking for a smaller DSLR to take on hikes. Had a horrible experience in a local camera store, so we did our own research and we decided to buy this. Bought from amazon due to longer return period and easy returns. She loves it and we are keeping it. Just got a neoprene cover so it can be safely stashed in a backpack. Bought it over other options….Nikon D3100 and D3200.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera!!!!
Reviews.Author: Seth Osborne
Reviews.Content: I wanted a compact DSLR camera that I could take anywhere. I could not be more pleased with this camera. I took it to Colorado on a ski trip and it took GREAT pictures of the mountains and the group I traveled with.

Reviews.Title: great entrylevel DSLR
Reviews.Author: Ronald J. Cichocki
Reviews.Content: I'm a novice photographer, learning to piece together the things it takes to take a good picture. Most of my shots are landscape. The Canon SL1 with its smaller footprint, fits into my hands quite well. The quality of the pics I've taken so far have been GREAT but mostly experimental as I am still figuring out the controls of the SL1. The camera is lightweight, I have been using either a Canon 50mm 1.8 lense or a Canon 35-80mm lens for my landscape shots. I believe that this camera will fill the bill for me.

Reviews.Title: Light weight makes it a winner.
Reviews.Author: E. Greynolds
Reviews.Content: I just cannot lug my 5D II or my 7D for the casual shooting I do.  This camera is just what I wanted,  I can carry the camera with the kit zoom or a prime without a problem.  The photos look great.I am delighted with it.

Reviews.Title: Moved up
Reviews.Author: Geo
Reviews.Content: Couldn't be happier, moved up from an older digital rebel, great price and received it in record time. The camera is fantastic so many features plus video.

Reviews.Title: great little camera
Reviews.Author: R. Laurito "doowopa"
Reviews.Content: been using a canon can for yearsfinally decided to upgradeI like everything about it.the. STM lens is perfect for videos very quiet

Reviews.Title: So far a fantastic DSLR
Reviews.Author: Ski SanDiego
Reviews.Content: Had if for a few weeks, so far the image quality is far better than my Rebel XTi.  Will update as i spend more time with it.

Reviews.Title: Great camera!
Reviews.Author: Sonya Shumway
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for my husband for Christmas & he used it extensible during a family trip to Disney World. We could not be more pleased with the quality of the photos. Excellent choice!

Reviews.Title: good picture quality in a small package
Reviews.Author: Kelli L. Vance
Reviews.Content: This camera delivers crisp images in a user friendly package. Its size is manageable but it does so much more than a point and shoot. It does have a limited zoom ability and so I will most like be purchasing a lens to increase the range of the camera.

Reviews.Title: Great for new DSLR users
Reviews.Author: Carlos M
Reviews.Content: For someone coming from regular or advanced P&S; cameras this is the perfect camera to move up to. The user interface is great and makes you enjoy taking pictures and learn the basics of photography. The camera is very easy to use and you will be using in manual in no time; wondering why it took you so long to move up to camera that gives you total control of how you want the images to come out.Picture/video quality on the camera is excellent; and pretty much identical to its big brother, the t5i. The pictures come out looking sharp and with accurate colors in both good light and in low light conditions. You can pump up the ISO and still get very usable images in low light.The size and weight of the camera is great for when you are traveling and want to keep your weight down when doing alot of walking. The size/weight reduction is big enough to notice and appreciate the reduced weight/size but still have an adequate grip and button configuration to enhance the photographing experience.The cons are that it does not have a swiveling screen. There have been a couple of times that I had wished it had, specially when shooting video. Also, the 40mm pancake is great for the camera, and really make it a compact set up; but I wish Canon would come out with pancakes with a wider focal length to truly bring out the compactness of the camera.

Reviews.Title: GREAT CAMAREA
Reviews.Author: MICHAEL BOSTIC
Reviews.Content: BOUGHT THIS CAMAREA FOR MY DAUGHTER. THE CAMERA IS EASY TO USE AND TAKES GREAT PICS. I RECIEVED THE ORDER TWO DAYS EARLY RIGHT IN TIME FOR CHRISTMAS

Reviews.Title: Excellent Walk Around DSLR
Reviews.Author: B. Badurek
Reviews.Content: I had debated between purchasing the Canon Rebel SL1 or the Canon Rebel T5i for many months. They were both released in 2013 and have similar features. The T5i has more bells and whistles whereas the SL1 is much smaller and lighter. My wife preferred the SL1 because what good is a camera that you'll never want to lug around all day.Amazon had a great price on the SL1 over the holidays and that was the deciding factor. I am quite happy with the purchase! This camera is really light and fun to use! The 18-55mm lens is very fast and versatile. I also purchased the Canon 40mm pancake lens. With the 40mm lens the camera is balanced, compact, and light. The perfect walk around combo for a long day at the beach or amusement park! I even keep the 40mm lens on the camera in the storage bag so it is always ready to go at a moments notice.I would definitely recommend this camera to anyone who wants something much better than a point and shoot!

Reviews.Title: From a beginning photographer
Reviews.Author: Justin
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera based on prior reviews stating that it is a good camera for someone who is starting to learn about photography.  As a beginner I am happy to say that I have found this camera extremely easy to use.  Making adjustments of the settings for lighting conditions is extremely easy and the camera is also incredibly light.I did extensive research on different cameras and I can honestly say that this camera provided some impressive specs for the money.  Similar cameras of other brands cost significantly more for what you get with this Canon.  The only downside is that the lens is pretty average.  That said, I find that it does the job for someone starting with photography like me.  I will eventually replace the lens, but without a doubt this camera deserves the 5-star rating that I have given it.

Reviews.Title: Quality camera for all photography types.
Reviews.Author: Charles
Reviews.Content: Love everything about this camera!! The size is perfect for a digital SLR. Pictures look amazing. Lots of photo features for increased creativity. This is my new travel and adventure camera!

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Camera, a giant leap for point and shooters
Reviews.Author: Eran Cohen
Reviews.Content: The Canon SL-1 is my first DSLR. I have been photographing with it frequently for about a month now.A famous photographer says "your camera doesn't matter" - and it's rings true - if you have the SL-1.Yes, you can take great pictures with almost any camera, even the simplest point and shoot (P&S;), but the SL-1, and probably other leading brands DSLRs, give the photographer an edge I experienced firsthand.So, what is this edge?If I'd have to sum it up in one word, it would be "technology"; it encapsulates everything that is so super about this camera.The DSLR state of the art technology advantages:- Better handling and responding to the varying stages of light anywhere that result in providing fantastic pictures.- Faster tracking, focusing and shooting moving subjects of all kinds. If you are a first time DSLR buyer you'd be amazed at the easiness in which the camera does it and then you'll probably ask yourself: "why haven't I upgraded earlier?"- Having a real viewfinder. Most amateur Digital-era point and shooters don't really understand the necessity of a relatively small viewfinder, when photographic subjects can be seen on a big LCD screen (aka "live-view").Ever since I got the SL-1 I don't use the live-view anymore.Why? Because of the now-obvious advantages:* Immediate response to photographing possibilities.* Far less energy consumption compared to live-view which allows taking many more pictures between each battery charge.* Framing and composing tend to be better. This is debatable, but I think that is is so because the eye is isolated from nuisances and distractions, and is closer to the frame and final composition.- The ability to change lenses. You can do just fine with just one kind of lens, but being able to change lenses, reach out further or closer than ever possible otherwise and achieve top-quality results is exciting and liberating.The SL-1 is good-looking, easy to handle and operate, its build quality and responsive touch screen are top notch.I see only one disadvantage compared to a P&S;: it is relatively bigger - but remember that this camera offers the smallest DSLR package available today in a bargain price.I have been an amateur photographer for more than 10 years, taking pictures with P&S; cameras. Ever since I purchased this camera I feel like a pro. I just can't stop taking pictures, and the results are way beyond my expectations. With the SL-1 I do feel like I'm ready for anything, and I hope so will you.

Reviews.Title: Small Camera with Mighty Features
Reviews.Author: Su-Z-Q "Mystery Lover"
Reviews.Content: I bought this as a 3rd camera because I wanted something a little smaller to carry more easily. It looked smaller in the pictures and I had hoped for something more pocket sized, but this camera is really great. It's amazing for it's size with all the features it has. I even can buy other lenses for it to increase it's versatility. I haven't had a chance to use it much, but can see it really has a place in my camera family. As a semi-pro photographer (working to become a pro) I am always eager to learn more and use different equipment and styles and this little Canon will be a chance to experience new angles. I'm very glad I bought it!

Reviews.Title: Best Camera Yet!
Reviews.Author: murff5
Reviews.Content: Bought for my wife to replace her Rebel XS. Unbelievable upgrade. Touch screen, 18 megapixel, perfect pictures.Simple to use, light weight, and compact. The best Canon yet.

Reviews.Title: So far - it's great
Reviews.Author: Jayebee
Reviews.Content: I have only had this camera for a month but I like it.  Without getting into technical detail (there are plenty of reviews for that) it is very light and comfortable to use.  I have had Canon cameras in the past so this was very easy to operate.  Bottom line, it's light, simple to use, takes great photos and has plenty of options for adjusting your exposures.  I hope to update this review in six months.

Reviews.Title: Total casual photo taker
Reviews.Author: MrsMoeJoe
Reviews.Content: I consulted a photographer friend when making my purchase. I upgraded from the rebel xsi I bought in 2008. The new camera is small, uses the lenses I bought for my previous camera, has a touch screen, and does video. It was a big upgrade for me since my old model was not that impressive of a dslr and it cost me less then that camera did years ago. I'm very happy with my purchase.

Reviews.Title: Lightest SLR
Reviews.Author: Kevin Banders
Reviews.Content: This is one fabulous camera for the serious amateur.  Combined with a Sigma lens it weighs less than 2 lbs.  So easy to lug around and takes beautiful photos.  Buy it.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for pro-am photographers and videodabblers
Reviews.Author: Computer Guy
Reviews.Content: My wife has been a photographer for 15 years. One thing that has always been an issue with SLRs and DSLRs has been the size of the cameras. She is a petite woman with small hands and this camera is a perfect fit.It has all the technical and visual expertise one expects from Canon. It takes great pictures and video and has on-screen tips available to help out beginners, without taking away the advanced choices a pro would be interested in.

Reviews.Title: A really good DSLR for a great price
Reviews.Author: A. Williams
Reviews.Content: When I compare the SL1 with my older Rebel t4i, The SL1 in every case meets or exceeds the performance of the older camera, and weighs 6 oz. less. The one notable feature absent from the SL1 is the articulated LCD screen, which is handy occasionally, but I can live without it, given the lower price, lighter weight, and better video capability.

Reviews.Title: A solid little marvel
Reviews.Author: Lipps
Reviews.Content: I did lots of research before I bought this camera, and I am happy to say I am delighted with it. It feels solidly built and it's small size is perfectly proportioned for my hand. Photography is an avocation, so I am not a novice. I found basic controls for manual shots quite intuitive. The various buttons and touch screen options are well placed, and after just a few weeks my fingers find the buttons and control wheel without having to look for them.The multitude of functions is quite impressive. In addition to the manual, I watched some youtube tutorials because this little camera is overvlowing with settings, options and functions. I discovered it will even change my socks every Tuesday. I guess I am on my own the rest of the week!

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Value
Reviews.Author: Long Island Dad
Reviews.Content: We already have many cameras in our house but I wanted something for my wife that was small enough for her to want to use it (rather than just grabbing her Canon S120 as usual) but also versatile enough to be able to use my extensive collection of Canon lenses and flashes. We purchased this kit for only $499 a few months ago and so far it's been lovely to use. It fits my wife's hands perfectly and it's not so small that I'm not comfortable using it either. The kit lens is great but a bit limiting at just 55mm on the long end. If you plan on getting the longer zoom to supplement it, fine. But if you want to not have to switch lenses often and want more reach, I highly recommend getting just the body (for under $400) and then getting the Canon EF-S 18-135 STM for about $400 more. This latter setup is actually what we eventually did and we gave this first kit as a gift.

Reviews.Title: 1st DSLR a Winner
Reviews.Author: Ronnie L. Shank
Reviews.Content: I moved up from a canon point and shoot and what a nice change . The size and weight are perfect. I bought a book fit dummies to help learn this camera and I'd suggest this for those experiencing their 1st DSLR. The Auto function fits most my needs and the video as well. When you gave special situations to shoot , the touch screen makes it easy to navigate the many already programmed set ups for that special effect. I'd buy this camera again !

Reviews.Title: Welcome Addition to Canon Line
Reviews.Author: Nicholson
Reviews.Content: Other reviewers have given good coverage of the technical aspects.Since I am somewhat of a camera junky and have purchased several cameras and lenses I will compare this camera to others. The real decision one has to make is which frame sizes to buy. I  have a full frame Canon 5DMKlll. This will use all of the Canon EF,lenses,is big,expensive,heavy and good.I also had a Canon 7D. It has the a so-called 1.6 sensor  is smaller than the full frame sensor,such that the picture will be cropped down. For example a 50mm full frame lens would give you a picture size the same as an 80mm full frame lens. 50mm times 1.6 = 80mm. This camera will use Canon EF lenses and Canon EF-S (S for small) lenses. EF-S lenses can't be used on full frame cameras. The 7D will use those S lenses and the EF lenses but weighs about as much as the  full frame 5D. Enter,the SL-1, the perfect solution. I was able to sell my 7D body ( which has its own merits,especially for pros and movie makers) and more than pay for a new SL-1 body! Now I can use  those EF -S lenses plus my other Canon lenses on a great lightweight platform.For the  new camera buyer without a lot Canon lenses,one must consider other options. For a good all around camera the  Canon EF Ti5 with the swing out screen would be better but I wanted the lightest most compact unit.Also to consider are the newer micro four thirds cameras.Their  sensor screens are one half the size of a full frame camera sensors and are capable of amazing performance. For all intents they are as good as cameras with 1.6 sensors. Both Olympus and Panasonic have excellent models which can take stunning photographs. The big advantage is that not only the camera bodies but the lenses and lighter. There is a different learning curve for using them. You have no option buy to learn to set the camera ,since there are so many complicated buttons and menu's you are always accidentally resetting the cameras to a different setting. Once you learn how to control them they are tremendous performers that come in a small light format. The Canon cameras will always be heavy due to the lenses.  I now actively use both my Canon cameras and my Olympus and Panasonic cameras. My most economical recommendation is the Olympus EPL-5, a pocket full of the little prime lenses (14MM,20MM 45mm) for some amazing pictures. One benefit of micro four thirds is that all brands are interchangeable. So I can use Panasonic lenses on Olympus cameras.

Reviews.Title: A GREAT small camera: no more EVIL or MILCs for me!
Reviews.Author: R. Kaufmann
Reviews.Content: I've gone through a few micro-4/3'rds and Sony NEX cameras, and have been basically displeased with all of them.  Either the lens choices are less than ideal (hello, Sony), the upgrade cycle is way too long (hello, Oly and Panny) -- or maybe it's just that for "real" photography I use the big-boy Canons (1d and 6d) and value the ability to have one pool of lenses and flashes.Whatever the root cause, this thing is now always in my work backpack.  It's small enough so that I don't mind hauling it around, and the quality is good enough for my needs.  I own a few STM lenses at this point.  The 18-135 STM is my favorite: very light, great range, and great images.  The 40 STM pancake is too tele for general use, and too wide for portraits.  It's a lens cap at this point!  I'm keeping the 18-55 STM for a while for those "really light" days, but its not going to be heavily in rotation.And my favorite lens, believe it or not?  The 8-15 circular fisheye zoom.  Great results, and a pleasure to use.Oh, and the touchscreen is stonking brilliant!  I almost fainted the first time I swiped, pinched and zoomed a picture on playback.  Tapping to focus is also a blast.  Call me an old dog, but that's one trick I learned very quickly.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Travel Camera
Reviews.Author: daniel
Reviews.Content: Very little to add to the prior excellent reviews.  I was worried about the small size coming from the 7D and being a big guy but it fits just perfectly in your hand. The shutter is just where it should be.  I plan on using this with the 18-135 STM and the 40mm as a travel combo.  Nice addition to a larger body as you can share the entire line of lens.

Reviews.Title: best camera
Reviews.Author: Crystal
Reviews.Content: I have been waiting to buy this camera and i am so glad that i did. is so light weight (until i put the lens on, then it ads on the weight) and it fits perfectly in purse for on the go.

Reviews.Title: A great camera with a great lens and a good price, an all around champion.
Reviews.Author: pierre rochat
Reviews.Content: The best camera I ever owned.There are so many features I like about this camera, easy and light, great lens.i have not try the video yet.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Matt
Reviews.Content: This camera is just what my wife and I as amateur photogs were looking for.  We have been using the camera as much as possible indoors and out and have gotten some great shots already!  Lots more time with the camera getting familiar and working on techniques is definitely required, but we enjoy the camera very much!

Reviews.Title: Great Camera.  Period
Reviews.Author: ENZYMES "natureskid"
Reviews.Content: Short but sweet.  Function and size make this a great camera. I replaced  my Rebel XTi and could be happier.  Read details on Amazon s Web page and compare functions you are interested in.

Reviews.Title: Love This Canon
Reviews.Author: NJ Granna
Reviews.Content: Great little camera and just what I needed!  I hate the weight of my other Canon so this is now my go to for all my shooting.  I especially love it with my macro, for 99% of my shots, no tripod needed.Go ahead, buy it.  You won't regret your purchase.

Reviews.Title: Great Travel Camera
Reviews.Author: W. Austin
Reviews.Content: Great on size and features - the smallest real SLR you can find.  I really like the menus and touch screen display.  This is an upgrade from an old Rebel XT I had.  I like it much better.

Reviews.Title: Great camera!
Reviews.Author: LilWoolf "LilWoolf"
Reviews.Content: I received this in LIGHTNING SPEED and it was exactly what I was hoping for.  I ordered it just before I left on a cruise and I really enjoyed taking pictures with it.  I still have lots to learn about it, but for a novice, it takes BEAUTIFUL pictures!!!Thankyou.

Reviews.Title: Small, Light, and Good...but not great
Reviews.Author: Dan
Reviews.Content: The SL1 was significantly smaller than other DSLRs, especially when I used the Canon 40mm Pancake lens which I consider a must have with this camera. It functioned as good as any other Canon rebel camera out there, but not any better. If you have or have looked at the Canon T4i, do not buy the Canon SL1, except for the small size. Canon has made no progress in sensor tech, video quality, or low light performance. I also tested the SL1 up against my Canon 7D (4 years old) and Nikon D7100 and the SL1 was by far the worst of the bunch for low light performance, even against the 4 year old Canon 7D's 18MP sensor. That took me by surprise. You can see the review on youtube under 'learningcameras' if you would like to see the full details. Overall, I would only buy it if you needed the small compact size.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic DSLR in the palm of your hand..
Reviews.Author: MCf
Reviews.Content: I travel every week and found my point and shoot lacking while my EOS 7D far too big to lug around.Thanks to Canon I have the SL1 and so far am extremely pleased with the size, functionality and the pictures are excellent.I am using the 40mm F2.8 pancake STM lens and carry a Tamron 18-270 separately.IMHO a great camera for travelers who want a DSLR!

Reviews.Title: My Baby or Was
Reviews.Author: Pokerbluff "Pokerbluff"
Reviews.Content: This is a small SLR Camera. The ISO goes to 25600. The quality is ok up to 6400 ISO. It is still nice having 25600 in case you need it.It has a special STM lens that is made for video. The IS is also made for video. It is compatible with Ultra High Speed cards. The camera body weights 13 ounces. The camera has HDR, filters, picture styles and more. The battery does not last a real long time. It depends on how much you use the touch screen and video. Video will kill the battery fast.It has an internal mono microphone but an external port for a stereo microphone. The internal microphone is of no use, so plan on getting an external one or some other method of recording sound. It will shoot at 4 frames a second. I was not happy that the battery compartment and the memory card are the same.  The camera would last longer if the battery was different that the card. That was my thought's anyway. I was not happy that the cover for the port that USB to go to the PC is just a piece of rubber.It would be better to use a card reader. I did not have a card reader though. I do not expect it to last a long time. I do have a point and shoot that is like that that has lasted for many years but I have been very careful. I liked the weight and the ISO the most of the camera. I do not like the 18-55 lens. It does not give me enough distance. I would have preferred the 18-135 lens. The camera was sold with a 18-135 lens in the early days but They were sold very rarely later.I never got to try the 55-250 IS lens. The touch screen is fun but I could live without it also. The camera does have auto-focus during video but I did not use it. I do advice to get an extra battery. I charged mine 100's of times.It is a fun camera but you will have to baby it for it to last.I only had the camera for two months and then had to give it back.I took care of it while I had it. Canon's 50 1.8 does not hold up well. So you will probablyhave to get a 50 1.4 to use with it.Also there is nothing to protect the back screen from scratches. There is also no place to put anythingto protect the camera.This cameras does use a hybrid II system that is much faster than the hybrid I on the T5I. The Hybrid II is the auto-focus during video. or live view. How good is the picture quality? I am not sure but I did think it was much better than a Nikon D40 I once had.The camera also has touch focus in live view.
