The camera does not have kelvin and does not have the number of ISO settings that are in the 60D.The extra settings for the ISO are in the camera but you can not see them as they are turned off. There does exist software that can turn on the extra ISO settings. There is also a magnifier for manual focus. I do not think it works as a magnifier during movies like I have read that the T3I is suppose to do.

Reviews.Title: Absolutely fantastic dSLR
Reviews.Author: Adam Fields
Reviews.Content: I've been a Canon user for many years, starting with the Rebel, then the Rebel XT, then the XTi. Then I stepped up to the 40D for better image quality and features, but when it came time to replace that, the Rebel line had vastly improved and I went to the T3i for more portability. The SL1 is the latest in that progression, and it is noticeably smaller and lighter in my bag than even the T3i (and looking back on the 40D, I can't imagine why I ever wanted to carry that around - it's huge in comparison), and the image quality is outstanding. (A note: I got one on pre-order when it was first released, and the first one had a defective image processor or sensor - it crushed all of the shadow detail. The replacement has not had any issues, but if the image quality is not up to snuff, you should consider replacing it.) Some have found the grip too small, but it's very comfortable for me.Paired with the 18-135 STM lens or the 40mm pancake, this is an outstanding walkaround camera, with the flexibility to use higher end lenses if needed.

Reviews.Title: Video no good
Reviews.Author: L. Qi
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera mainly for shooting kids videos and photos, I'd say maybe 50% each. So I need a camera that's good at both. With the phase detection AF and STM lens I thought I found the exact one for my application.I shot some video of my daughter playing piano yesterday. Lens is the 40mm F2.8 STM, camera was mounted on a sturdy tripod, room was well lighted(I used combined 800w light bulbs). The camera shift focus back and forth for some unknown reason. I got this jumpy video that every couple of seconds my daughter's figure would get blurred and then sharp again.I could have turned the AF off and just rely on manual focus in this particular case, but I expect the AF to work much better than this!Bottom: If you just need a camera to take photo then this is ok, but if you need to shoot both video and photo, you probably will be disappointed just like me

Reviews.Title: great camera
Reviews.Author: Carl Wang
Reviews.Content: It works well, and meet all my expectations.  If I know better, I will not buy the one come with the Lens, because I purchase a better zoom lens.

Reviews.Title: very good cam and way smaller than i expected
Reviews.Author: chaik george
Reviews.Content: even though I looked at them in stores its not the same as putting your lens on it and having it in your handsive had it for a while now an it takes great pics of my 8 month old daughter...in low lightand takes great video as well

Reviews.Title: Small but very limited in purpose
Reviews.Author: AG "Sooners"
Reviews.Content: I have used the 30/40/60D/5D3 and currently 6D. Image quality is consistent with other EOS cameras. No surprises and it performs consistently.Canon did a good job of reducing the size, but the depth is still about the same. It only remains well balanced with the kit lens which is very low-end quality. The body and lens are made in Taiwan and very plastic.Live view AF is much-much faster than my Canon 6D, but it makes a racket.The LCD is an excellent touchscreen on par with smartphone response. While it doesn't have the controls of a 6D/60D, the touchscreen buttons do make up some ground.Overall, it's good if you are just planning to use the kit lens or a small prime (40mm).- For about 6oz. more weight and the same cost, the T4i is the better option.- If you want a small APS-C camera, then the NEX models are substantially smaller and lighter.- If you want to use Live View a lot for stills, then you are better off with the Sony SLT-A57.- This is no substitute for the m4/3 OM-D as it is aimed for a different group.The SL1 was meant for the mass market, not enthusiasts or pros.Update 6/26/13: I paired this body with the newest Sigma 18-250mmm lens for a trip. This is a nice small all-in-one package and the results are excellent. The touch screen response is great. Too bad we don't have that on the 5D/6D lines.Update 07/11/13: I ended up not using the Sigma due to some mechanical problems with that lens. Paired SL1 with the 18-135 STM, which is still light, but not as small. SL1 still provides reliable image quality.

Reviews.Title: Good camera, but going a step above is better $value$
Reviews.Author: Andi C Bair
Reviews.Content: Canon EOS Rebel SL1 is a DSLR camera, that is a small step above the Canon Rebel T3i. . Let me use my usual disclaimer, and admit that with so many good cameras around, it is more about what mix of traits or features you are looking for.On that note, the camera's trait mix is as follows. It is a DSLR with 18 megapixels resolution. Probably the most important point for this class of cameras is the sensor size, which is APS-C. That's just one step below 35mm Full frame.It has an optical viewfinder, which works through a pentaprism. That is the classical SLR construction. You are using the properties of light to view the subject before and during the shot. The purists would argue this is the way it was supposed to be- that is, with minimal electronic intervention. As in most Canon DSLRs, it has a Dioptric adjustment to make it easy for people with glasses to use the viewfinder. Also, you can preview depth of field. The dust deletion mechanism includes a software adjustment for removing/modifying the affected pixels, self-cleaning sensor, and manual cleaning.The ISO rating is 25,600 which makes it work better in low light. The video is a Full HD- that is 1920x1080 resolution. The camera gives you the option to control the exposure  manually. It does have an external flash option. You would need that for portraits, at least. The LCD screen resolution is a whopping 1,040,000. The sustainable burst rate- for fast action- is 4 frames per second. That is a bit low for DSLRs. The camera also does RAW processing which is useful if you did not want to be limited by JPEG storage only. The camera body weighs 407 grams, which is very light compared to other DSLRs. In that respect, the SL1 gives users the best of both worlds- SLR characteristics with light weight. That holds up well against the newer challenger of this category of cameras- the mirrorless.The SL1 has a couple of small, but significant changes over the T3i. It has a higher ISO rating, and a much improver LCD screen. Most importantly, it has a newer image processor- Digic 5 instead of Digic 4.A nice camera, and a lot improved compared to its predecessor. But still somewhat dated when it comes to some traits, compared to other DSLRs.

Reviews.Title: Doesn't Anyone Hear the Noise?
Reviews.Author: thebutterfly
Reviews.Content: I just came to this camera from a 5D Mark II.  Simply can't hold it steady anymore due to arthritis and you can't always use a tripod, which I hate anyway.I have been reading reviews since before and after my purchase.  With the exception of one review (not on this site), no one has mentioned the noise. This is astounding to me as I find it unacceptable.  Shooting at the highest resolution (RAW) produces a document file size of approximately 11.5" x 17.5" with the maximum resolution of 5184 x 3456 pixels (somewhat incongruous).  Even without cropping, which I most always do, the noise is unbearable and makes it almost impossible to obtain a "tack sharp" image. I know that I shouldn't compare my 5D MKII to this camera, but same images taken by both cameras, same settings, and same lighting conditions produced a vastly different quality.  Even if 11 x 17 would be my largest print size, and it isn't, I would not be happy with it.  Noise reduction, whether in the camera or with software, always softens the image.I wanted to love this camera because of its weight (and I do love the touch screen).  I may contact Canon.  Maybe I'm doing something wrong with my camera settings.  I really hope I'm doing something wrong.Has anyone else had the same experience or have any suggestions?

Reviews.Title: A great little camera!
Reviews.Author: G. Morris
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to use with one single Canon lens I have; the new 35mm IS lens.  This DSLR body and that lens make a near perfect match.  This body is a little bit small for my hand and grip but surprisingly when the 35mm IS lens is mounted to this body (and the lens is nearly as large as this camera body) it creates a very easily hand-holdable pair.This Canon body has all the buttons and settings one needs for basic shooting and also basic video shooting.  The video capability mostly keeps up with my 18-month old granddaughter as she zips around and that's a significant plus for this camera and it's auto-focusing ability.The reason I knocked this camera body down from five-stars to four-stars is that the image quality is not as good as I'd have expected.  Specifically, the images suffer from a bit more noise than they should have.  I do most of my shooting at ISO 200 to ISO 400.  When the images are viewed in Photoshop at 100%, it's clear that a healthy dose of noise reduction needs to be applied.  The camera does produce decent image detail and contrast but Canon's 18MP sensors (at least in this camera and the 7D which I previously owned) just fall a little short of what the lenses are capable of putting on the sensor.Overall, this is a very good camera and if one is not as image-quality obsessed as I tend to be and you don't put any giant lenses on this very small body (such as the 100-400 push pull L zoom lens), then you'll probably be 5-star happy.  With smallish lenses, I do recommend this Canon camera body.

Reviews.Title: I DIDN'T LOVE IT
Reviews.Author: tczig
Reviews.Content: I waited a long time to buy this camera; I am a Canon girl.  I have a couple point and shoots, and another Rebel that is old.  What attracted me to it was the small size; I loved that.  I bought it with the 250mm IS zoom lens.It is indeed small and very lightweight.  There is most definitely a difference in the heaviness of it compared to my friend's big Canon SLR.  In trying it out, I used both lenses.  Even with the zoom on it, it is still very light and easily to manage. That much, I liked about it.I also LOVED the touch screen.  When I bought it, the guy told me it had touch screen.  I figured I would never use that.  But, I tried it and really liked it - it makes it very convenient to change settings.  And, once you go back to shooting, the touch screen is disengaged - in otherwords, if you bump the camera on your side while walking, the touch screen does not activate.  Good feature.I am by no means a professional photographer.  But, I know my way around a camera.  I don't like all the fancy settings.  I use P or manual, and sometimes landscape.  I prefer to monitor my aperature and shutter speed rather than letting the camera do it all automatically.  I have no use for any kind of video, so I didn't even use the video on this camera, not even to try it.I did try out the different settings just to see how they were.Overall, it takes decent photographs.  But, my problem with it was the closeups.  I could NOT get a decent closeup of things like the centers of flowers, or a bird's eye.  If I was taking a photo of some scenery around a lake, or a blue sky, the photos were good.  I don't like using the "closeup" setting because you cannot adjust the focus point (if you want the focus only in the center, you can't use the closeup setting - or if you can, I could NOT find a way to do it).  My other Rebel had this same issue so I would never use the closeup setting.  When you focos on something in the closeup setting, it will not necessarily put the focus point on what you want.  I hope I am explaining that properly.  But, the P setting, you can put the focus in the center, and it stays there.I shot some photos in our national park, and at a state park.  I took photos of birds, landscapes, trees, etc.  I just was not blown away by the photographs.I bought the camera to replace my Canon Rebel XS which I bought in 2009 but have dropped too many times.  That old camera takes better photos than this little one. And, unfortunately, what attracted me to the camera - the light weight and small size - ended up being something I don't like.  Because it is so light, sometimes it's hard to steady - if that makes sense.Maybe a professional using the numerous settings might like this camera, but I didn't.  If it would maybe be $150.00, I would have kept it - but, it was too expensive for me not to love it.  I packed it up and returned it.

Reviews.Author: byron lemmond
Reviews.Content: Canon SL1 body:I waited on pre-order list from April until it was available, and Amazon shipped in May. I shot a few still images to get familiar with controls and took it on August vacation in Maine. Part way through the vacation, first thing one morning, the camera wouldn't turn on. Wouldn't turn on with numerous batteries. So after about 2000 shots and 90-95 days of operation, the camera was a brick. If you buy an SL1 always be sure to carry a backup camera for special moments you want to capture.I extracted the memory card and started processing the images I did get (Canon software is moderately difficult to use with poor documentation, can't really recommend it for moderate - casual user).If I didn't have so much invested in Canon lenses, I would have purchased something from another manufacturer (Nikon?)Poor hardware quality, very pedestrian software = very unsatisfied customer (it's my 4th Canon and maybe my last).I hope anyone who reads this has better luck with theirs, I wish you well as I wait for Canon to repair mine.

Reviews.Title: Lemme tell you why I got a different Canon Rebel instead of this one while we have a cup of coffee
Reviews.Author: Whipple McTeelson the Third "Purveryor of Mad...
Reviews.Content: I knew as soon as I picked up this camera at the local brick and mortal that I wasn't going to buy it.  I got the Canon Rebel T3i instead.  Do I regret it?  Not a chance.  Now that's a great camera the T3i- takes great pics and easy to use.So why even write a review on a different product I didn't buy?  Sometimes I wished I had come across a review on a product somebody thought about but ultimately passed over for something else.  Gotta look at all the angles.  I picked up the SL1 and just didn't like it's light-weightiness.  If I'm slapping down $650+ on an electronic device I don't want less substantial build, body, chassis, design and heft.  All these electronics that are becoming smaller, slimmer and lighter in the pants pocket is just nonsense.  I got man hands.  It may all be good and fine for women to put in their purses but not for this guy.  I don't want to lose something in the city bus cause I forgot the silly thing was even there and I got off the stop to get a falafel.I want a camera that feels like I'm hunting for some big game shots in Africa on a safari and if need be I can club a wildebeest in the snoot if he ventures too closely.  And don't worry; them wildebeests are very strong-one good whack is just gonna back him up half a step at most.  I want a camera that feels like a thousand dollars of pure precision craftsmanship in my paws; not some light airy snapper for me to take pics of the kids on the soccer field.Also the SL1 was a higher price without the same high quality everything compared to the T3i as per all the other reviews.  I sat down and read through the camera magazines, the cnet website, Amazon's official descriptions and perused all of 2 actual user reviews.  I'm sorry but I'm not leaving up some important decision over a camera that best be lasting me 10 years (cause I've had enough of the disposability of the $200 electronic products) and relying on user reviews.  I'm half convinced that almost all of the user reviews are either Canon employees or competing brand employees either over-hyping or bashing the products.  I say 'go to the professionals that know what they are talking about' cause anecdotal evidence is the realm of the fools.On a side note.  I did pick up a couple Nokia cameras and liked the feel but the demo mode on them weren't working right at the stores so I didn't bother really seriously considering them.

ProductInfo.Features:
Compact and lightweight DSLR featuring a newly-developed 18.0 Megapixel CMOS (APS-C) sensor, ISO 100-12800 (expandable to H: 25600) for stills and ISO-6400 (expandable to H: 12800) for videos for shooting from bright to dim light, and high performance DIGIC 5 Image Processor for exceptional image quality and speed.
9-point AF system (including a high-precision dual-cross f/2.8 center point) for exceptional autofocus performance when shooting with the viewfinder; new Hybrid CMOS AF II, which combines the advantages of high-speed phase-detection AF and high-precision contrast AF, provides a widened Hybrid CMOS AF focus area for increased autofocus speed and accuracy when shooting photos and movies in Live View.
High speed continuous shooting up to 4.0 fps allows you to capture all the action
EOS Full HD Movie mode with Movie Servo AF for continuous focus tracking of moving subjects, manual exposure control and multiple frame rates (1080: 30p (29.97) / 24p (23.976) / 25p, 720: 60p (59.94) / 50p, 480: 30p (29.97) / 25p), built-in monaural microphone, manual audio level adjustment, and Video Snapshot with editing for expanded movie shooting options.
Touch Screen Wide 3.0-inch Clear View LCD monitor II (approximately 1,040,000 dots) with smudge-resistant coating features multi-touch operation with direct access to functions for setting changes and Touch AF for an easy, intuitive experience and clear viewing when outdoors; an Optical Viewfinder with approx. 0.87x magnification makes subjects easier to see.
